utterances: Every Thursday, we hear what's in and what's out from our friends at Youth Radio in our series What's The New What?
Today, our story comes from Maine.
Outdoor enthusiasts there have been taking full moon adventures, paddling out on lakes and bays to celebrate the last week of summer.
What's new?
How people are riding the waters.
Molly Adams reports.
What's the new what?
Kayaking is the new canoeing.
The open-hulled canoe is classic Americana.
Boy Scouts don't kayak.
They canoe.
They even earn canoe badges, but lately, faster, sleeker, lighter kayaks have overshadowed and outsold the heavy lumbering canoe.
And who cares?
Well, we Mainers do.
Canoes are the main paddle craft.
They're a part of our history.
Mr.
ZIP KELLOGG (Author, ""The Whole Paddler's Catalog: Views, Reviews, and Resources"") A lot of place names here in Maine, Kennebec, Penobscot, Presumpscot, Machias, they're river names.
That's Zip Kellogg, the author of ""The Whole Paddler's Catalog.
They have names like that because the Native Americans were traveling on these rivers in their canoes, mostly.
My earliest memory of a canoe is falling out of it.
Maybe that's why kayaks sell better.
They don't tip as easily.
Zip doesn't think so.
It's when people get in it that things start to happen.
You can see how the canoe versus kayak debate gets personal.
But preferences aside, Maine's top paddling retailer, Johnson Outdoors, says kayaks are outselling canoes almost 3 to 1.
(Soundbite of flowing water)
I went to try out a kayak myself, something I haven't done in a couple of years.
Go ahead and get in there and get your butt as far back in the seat as it will go.
I'm in the Harraseeket Bay in Freeport, Maine on a kayak tour.
I meet Ken and Eric Desmitt there, a father-son pair from Ohio.
Yeah, I'd rather go kayaking than canoeing.
Is it because it's like faster, or...
It's easier, too.
Have you ever been canoeing before, Ken?
Many many years ago in the Boy Scouts.
That's the problem right there.
Kids these days, they learn how to paddle on a kayak, not a canoe like the Boy Scouts did and do.
Families are buying three or four kayaks apiece if they can afford it.
Two small or tandem kayaks for the kids, two for the adults.
That's a big shift from buying one canoe per family, and in Freeport, Maine, L.L.
Bean's Alice Andrenyak has canoes in stock.
They're just outnumbered.
Recreational kayaks are significantly up in sales.
This is a me boat, so people who have limited time can go off by themselves.
These me boats in personalized colors like Cloud and Sunrise are taking over, even as canoe sales remain steady.
In a sign of the times, an Old Town, Maine fixture, Old Town Canoes, is now called Old Town Canoes and Kayaks.
I feel somewhat wistful about the rise of the kayak.
I like canoes.
They're kind of dorky in a slow, sweet way, and you can meet a friend in the middle to share a sandwich.
Maybe in a few years, canoes will become an object of nostalgic lust and come back on top.
But for now here in Maine, kayaking is the new canoeing.
Molly Adams is from Blunt Radio.
She comes to us as part of the Youth Radio and Day to Day series What's The New What?
Last year, we brought you the story of ""Music Man"" Murray.
Murray Gershenz was looking for a buyer for the enormous record collection that was shelved in his store in Los Angeles.
Now, notice I said record.
Most of his music was, indeed, on old vinyl.
Murray was turning 90, and his overstuffed store was becoming more than he could handle.
(SOUNDBITE OF DOCUMENTARY, ""MUSIC MAN MURRAY"")
That's a clip from a film by Richard Parks about Music Man Murray.
Well, this week we got an email from Mr. Parks, telling us that Murray Gershenz has sold his music collection.
A fleet of 52-foot-long trucks formed a small convoy, to whisk his music to a new home.
Mr. Parks says that Murray is in fair health, and in good spirits.
Last year, we asked Murray Gershenz to close out our talk with a song.
It seems a nice thing to hear again today.
(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING)
: (Singing) Once I built a railroad, I made it run, made it race against time.
Once I built a railroad, now it's done.
Brother, can you spare a dime?
(Humming)
You do that song very beautifully, Murray.
: Thank you very much.
(SOUNDBITE OF SONG, ""BROTHER, CAN YOU SPARE A DIME?"")
From NPR News, this is NEWS & NOTES.
I'm Farai Chideya.
There's been talk of Billary, that would be Bill and Hillary Clinton, but what about Clobama or Obinton?
The two remaining Democratic presidential candidates, Senators Clinton and Obama, played nice at last night's debate in Los Angeles.
I also want to note that I was friends with Hillary Clinton before we started this campaign.
I will be friends with Hillary Clinton after this campaign is over.
Does that mean they've heard the message from Democratic Party insiders that they shouldn't tear themselves down before, well, the Republicans get to tear one of them down in the general election?
For more on the debate and the race, we've got Democratic strategist Jamal Simmons.
He was press secretary for the presidential campaigns of both Senator Bob Graham and General Wesley Clark.
And we have Republican strategist Angela McGlowan.
She's an analyst for Fox News and author of the best-selling book, ""Bamboozled: How Americans Are Being Exploited by the Lies of the Liberal Agenda.
Jamal and Angela, welcome back.
Thank you for having us.
Thank you.
So some folks expected last night's showdown to be a smack down.
Angela, were you surprised by what happened?
No.
I wasn't surprised and, you know what, I'm glad to see that they did kiss and make up because there is a saying, united we stand, divided we fall.
And being a black woman, I saw a lot of division in the black community because of the Obama-Clinton situation.

So I'm glad that they kept this civil, because even though I am Republican and I'm a strategist for the Republican Party, I want to have an intelligent debate, so people can make a decision not on emotion, not on race baiting, but actually on the issues.
Jamal, in terms of issues, there have been times when the focus was more on the economy including in this week's Republican debate.
But last night, there was a lot of talk about the war in Iraq and Afghanistan.
Senator Obama has repeatedly pointed out that he was opposed to the war from the start.
Let's listen to a comment from last night.
And I think it is much easier for us to have the argument when we have a nominee who says, I always thought this was a bad idea, this was a bad strategy.
(Soundbite of applause)
And that is an argument that I think we are going to have an easier time making if they can't turn around and say: But hold on a second, you supported this.
And that's part of the reason why I think that I would be the strongest nominee on this argument of national security.
(Soundbite of applause)

You know, some people have said, including some of the analysts we have on the show that there's less of a distinction between, for example, Senator John McCain and Senator Hillary Clinton than there is between Senator John McCain's views on the wars and Senator Obama.
Is Obama actually going to benefit from this issue?
Is this something, you know, especially given the economic issues being so close to people's hearts, is this something that's really a selling point for him?
It is something that's a selling point for him.
It's mostly the reason why he got into the race; I think to get started was to start to talk about this issue.
And it's the reason why people started to like him.
Senator Obama's in a pretty good place when it comes to the issue with the war on Iraq.
And also, I think, the general issue which is leadership and judgment, which is where he's really trying to make his case.
So that's the place where voters - where he's trying to get voters to make the judgment about him that it's not as much about experience if you don't have good judgment.
He's got good judgment.
And they should count him is his argument.
Now, Angelaâ€¦
Yes.
